concept.title: What's new in version 1.2
concept.shortdesc: Learn about the new features in version 1.2.

dlentry.dd: A production-ready Virtual Edition can be installed on an existing server running in supported hypervisors, or in the SoftLayer environment on a virtual server or a bare metal server. IBM MessageSight Virtual Edition can handle large numbers of connected clients and devices, and process high volumes of messages with consistent latency. Virtual Edition can be used in development, test, or production environments. For more information about IBM MessageSight Virtual Edition - including supported platforms, images, and license agreement types - see IBM MessageSight Virtual Edition.

You can use the new Protocol Plug-in SDK to extend protocol support beyond the protocols that are natively supported. Use the SDK to write Java plug-ins that you can then deploy in . The protocol plug-in feature is supported as a technical preview. For further information and to download the SDK, go to the IBM messaging community developerWorks website.
can now automatically configure appliances as an HA pair for you. You can use this feature by enabling High Availability and setting the High Availability Group.
For more information about automatically configuring appliances as an HA pair, see Configuring an IBM MessageSight appliance automatically.

The monitoring of subscriptions benefits from a new filter: Messaging Policy. This filter enables you to collect monitoring statistics and information about subscriptions that are using specific messaging policies.
The monitoring of endpoints benefits from a new statistic: WarnMsgs. This statistic is a count of the messages since reset that, when published, resulted in a warning. For more information, see .

New predefined queries are provided to help you monitor the health of :
For queues, Queues with Most Messages Expired and Queues with Least Messages Expired provide useful information to help you evaluate and improve the efficiency of messaging traffic. See .
For subscriptions, Subscriptions with Most Messages Expired, Subscriptions with Least Messages Expired, Subscriptions with Most Messages Discarded, and Subscriptions with Least Messages Discarded provide useful information to help you evaluate and improve the efficiency of messaging traffic. See .
Detailed statistics regarding the use of the persistent store are provided. For more information, see .

For more information about configuring the appliance to exploit the benefits of SNMP, see .

You can apply heuristic decisions to XA transaction branches that are in a prepared or heuristically complete state when is acting as a resource manager in a distributed transaction processing environment. In rare circumstances, such as during a long-lasting loss of connectivity with an external transaction manager, XA transaction branches can remain in these states and need to be committed, rolled back, or forgotten independently of the transaction manager. Using the or the command line, you can:
List XA transaction branches and view their state.
Commit or roll back an XA transaction branch that is in prepared state.
Forget a heuristically complete transaction branch. For more information about XA transaction completion, see Working with XA transactions.

You can easily implement publishing and subscription to topics for groups by using the ${GroupID} variable when you create or update your messaging policies. For more information about using this variable, see .
You can configure the server locale by using the locale set command. If a translation is not available for the specified locale, US English is used.

The preferred locale of the browser is automatically detected. This detection is independent of the configuration of the server locale. For example, the server locale might be configured in French but a user might access the by using the preferred locale of the browser which is Japanese.
For more information about configuring the server locale, see .

dlentry.dt: Maximum time for messages to exist for in
dlentry.dd: You can configure how long a sent or published message can exist for in . A new parameter, MaxMessageTimeToLive is available on the messaging policy to specify how long such messages can exist for. You can configure your messaging policies so that older, less important messages are cleared from . In this way, you can prevent newer publications from being rejected because there is no capacity for them.
For more information, see .

You can configure what behavior is applied when the number of messages in the buffer for a subscription reaches the Max Messages value. That is, when the buffer for a subscription is full. The behavior is configured in the messaging policy. You can choose to reject new messages, or to discard a percentage of the oldest messages on the buffer.
For more information, see .

You can apply updates to a messaging policy and these updates are applied dynamically to the subscriptions and publishers using the messaging policy. Any changes you make to the following parameters are applied dynamically:
DisconnectedClientNotification
MaxMessages
MaxMessagesBehavior
MaxMessageTimeToLive
For more information, see .

Messaging policies that you do not need can be deleted, but will be kept available until they are no longer in use by subscribers or publishers. This allows you to control resources by modifying the dynamic update properties of the messaging policy which is pending deletion. The deletion automatically occurs at the point when the messaging policy is no longer in use.
For more information, see if you are using the , or if you are using the command line interface.

So that you can see how many users of a messaging policy would be affected by a dynamic update, a new informational field, UseCount, is returned on the imaserver show MessagingPolicy command and in the . This numeric field represents the number of objects on the server that are using the messaging policy.

The value of UseCount is also significant when messaging policies are to be deleted. If you attempt to delete a messaging policy and the value of UseCount is greater than zero, the messaging policy cannot be deleted but goes, instead, into a pending action status of Delete. When the value of UseCount reaches zero, the messaging policy is automatically deleted.

The UseCount value corresponds to the actual number of objects on the server that are using a messaging policy. You can use this information to help you to determine whether the messaging policy can be removed. Existing server optimizations mean that the server might not create objects for every publishing request - in some cases the server might remove objects when new requests come in. As a result, there is not a direct correlation between the UseCount value and the total number of combined subscriptions and publishing requests.

dlentry.dt: Log file rotation, purging, and offloading
dlentry.dd:
The log files for are automatically rotated after the file reaches a particular size. You can configure the log files in the following ways:
You can set the size at which a new log file is started, and you can set the number of files that are archived before the oldest file is deleted.
You can manually clear the archived log files and start a new log file rotation, by purging the log files.
You can configure automatic log transfers. The automatic log transfer copies log files to a remote system when the log file is archived on the server. For more information, see .
You can configure a remote syslog-compatible log server to which log messages can be forwarded. For more information, see .

You can use the OAuth protocol to allow a client application to connect to without providing a user ID or password. Instead, the client application is authenticated by an authorization server and an access token is returned to the client application. This token is used in place of a password to connect to .
supports OAuth 2.0. For more information, see .
now supports MQTT 3.1.1.
MQTT client applications can now benefit from the workload balancing and high availability advantages that global-shared subscriptions provide. For more information, see .

You can configure whether MQTT clients can connect using a cleanSession=0 setting. By default, MQTT clients are permitted to create durable subscriptions. Durable subscriptions consume more appliance resources than non-durable subscriptions. You can preserve appliance resources by configuring your connection policies to prevent clients from creating durable subscriptions. For more information, see .

You can configure whether MQTT clients can publish messages with a QoS of 1 or 2. By default, MQTT clients are permitted to publish persistent messages. Persistent messages consume more appliance resources than non-persistent messages. You can preserve appliance resources by configuring your connection policies to prevent clients from publishing persistent messages. For more information, see .

You can back up and restore the store. The facility to back up and restore the store is useful for disaster recovery planning and new machine deployments when the state of the store needs to be transferred. Backing up the store also makes reverting back to a previous level of firmware, should you ever need to, more straightforward. For more information about back and restore of the store, see .

dlentry.dt: Integrated Management Module II LAN interface IP address
dlentry.dd: You can now configure the Integrated Management Module II (IMM2) LAN interface located on the back of the appliance. The IMM2 service processor provides remote management and control of the appliance. You can use the IMM2 LAN interface to monitor hardware component status and power consumption on the appliance.
For more information about configuring the IMM2 LAN interface IP address, see Configuring the Integrated Management Module II interface.
